Mr.
Bixby
December 30, 1937
4.
You say the Chinese morale appears to be unbroken,
and going back to my conment on point #3 I can only
sat
that
this is
an assumption that can be proven only when the Japanese renew a vig-
orous offensive.
5.
What you say
about the Russian participation in the
war through supplying airplanes and pilots is extremely interesting,
if true, and I add that not to express any criticism of your state-
because infornation in this regard is so conflicting
that I doubt if any of us can really find out the truth at the pre-
Even so, Russian participation in the air,
unless carried
grand scale, cannot influence the
in China
to any
great extent.
The development of the civil war in
Spain has shown
great the effects of aviation on
the course of
ground warfare have been over-estimated by the air enthusiasts.
With regard to the Panay
incident, all evidence
proves conclusively
to the actions of young,
irres-
ponsible Japanese officers acting on
their own initiative, or whether
it was not perhaps deliberately ordered by superior Japanese officials
in China (not Tokyo) in the hope that it would bring about a "loss of
face" for the
British and Americans which would practically end occi-
dental prestige in. China,
with Japan, of course, gaining what the
Western nations had lost.
never know
the
truth.
I believe on this point we shall probably
Recent reports
that the Japanese are
contemplating a
large-scale attack on Canton gives me a great deal of
concern, because
if the Japanese military
are not impressed by
the American diplomatic
victory in the Panay incident, a similar incident may occur for the
same reasons in connection with the PAA clipper operating so near the
impending
scene of hostilities.
Furthermore, it seems to me that
large-scale military operations around Canton will involve serious
danger for the CNAC ship flying
the Hankow-Hong Kong route.
Of course
I know that these are possibilities which have not escaped you and
our Chinese associates and which are giving you much concern.
I hope you will continue to find the time to let me have
your views on the rapidly changing situation.
are about to inaugu-
rate a series of conferences at the Council on Foreign Relations which
should elicit some very interesting comment on the American policy in
the Far East and the Chinese situation, and I will not fail
to write
you anything which I think you will find of interest.
